Tate compares his work to that of contemporary Indian painters who abstract cultural icons, like feathers and horses.
He recasts American Indian musical icons such as flutes and drums.
Like many classically trained American Indians, Tate's gone back to explore his culture.

Not only are American Indians accessing contemporary expressions like this, but they're also going back and learning their traditions very, very well, you know, along with singing and dancing and language.
So they're actually both kind of moving parallel with each other.
Mixing European classical with indigenous and folk music is not new.
In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, European composers such as Antonin Dvorak and Bela Bartok drew from European folk music.
In 1935, Mexican composer Carlos Chavez wrote ""Sinfonia India,"" drawing on his country's indigenous music.
In the U.S., white classical composer Theodore Baker was one of the first to seriously study American Indian music in the late 1800s.
But it would take another half century before American Indians began to embrace classical music to express their cultural identity.
(Soundbite of music)
In the 1950s, composer Louis Ballard was inspired by Bartok to write chamber, orchestral, and choral music as well as ballets that incorporated Ballard's Quapaw and Cherokee background.
(Soundbite of music)
Ballard's work gained acclaim, and he continued to compose until his death two years ago.
But much of the work of others experimenting with the two styles remained below the radar until 1994 when the first convention of American Indian composers was held in Boulder, Colorado.
Since then, composers have received commissions, the American Composers Forum has started a First Nations Initiative, and some tribes have even funded education programs for young composers.
(Soundbite of music)
And the music is getting noticed both on and off the reservation by Indians who prefer country, hip-hop, or heavy metal.
I'm really surprised by how much people have liked it.
Mohawk cellist and composer Dawn Avery has studied with John Cage and played classical pop music and jazz.

One of the reasons is because there's a great appreciation for the sounds of the instruments, but also to hear our traditional music being represented in this way, I think people understand that there's an importance to that.
For Avery, it was the work of American Indian musical elder Louis Ballard, as well as a rediscovery of her heritage, that inspired her to compose with Indian themes.
(Soundbite of music)
But as she's become more intimate with her culture, she's also felt what she called an emotional tug-of-war by honoring her ancestors through a culture largely responsible for their subjugation.

The founder of Ebony and Jet magazines has died.
John H.
Johnson suffered heart failure after a long illness.
He was 87 years old.
NPR's Cheryl Corley has this remembrance.
Born in Arkansas, John H.
Johnson moved to Chicago with his mother and stepfather when he was 15.
He was the editor of his high school newspaper, and later, in 1942, he would start his own business, launching Johnson Publishing Company with a $500 loan secured by his mother's furniture.
The Negro Digest was his first magazine, but Ebony, published in 1945, and Jet magazine, which came six years later, would become the company's mainstays.
Unlike most other media of the time, they featured positive stories about blacks.
During an interview with NPR three years ago, Johnson said the magazines were like a ray of hope to African-Americans.
(Soundbite of 2002 interview)
Mr.
JOHN H.
JOHNSON (Publisher): It gave them the feeling that there were black people in other cities and in other countries like themselves who were doing well, and it inspired them to do better.
The magazines also played an influential role in the civil rights movement, especially when a 1955 cover photograph displayed the tattered body of lynched Chicago teen-ager Emmett Till.

Lerone Bennett Jr., the former executive director of Ebony, worked with Johnson for 51 years and helped write Johnson's autobiography, called ""Succeeding Against the Odds."" Bennett calls Johnson an American original, and a visionary who took advantage of opportunities.
Mr.
LERONE BENNETT Jr. (Former Executive Director, Ebony): He refused to concede that he couldn't do this or couldn't do that and he said determination, hard work will overcome almost any obstacle.
And one of the largest obstacles early on was persuading white corporations to advertise in his black magazines.
Ken Smikle, president of Target Market News, a company that specializes in African-American media, says such marketing exists on a national scale because Johnson broke the color line.

The history will remember him most for that by demanding respect for African-Americans he built not only a successful magazine but a successful business in a fashion like no one else had before or since, maybe.

John Johnson turned over control of the day-to-day operations of his publishing company to his daughter, Linda Johnson Rice, three years ago, but he remained active in the company affairs until just a few weeks before his death.
Cheryl Corley, NPR News, Chicago.
